item.title: Australia in danger of World Cup elimination after 'unbelievable' loss to Zimbabwe
item.description: Australia's hopes of advancing out of Group B are dealt an almighty blow as Zimbabwe claims one of the biggest upset wins in T20 World Cup history in Colombo.

item.title: How do you find modern dating? Share your highs and lows with us
item.description: Whether you've shed tears of joy, sadness or even laughter in the process, we want to hear it all — but keep it under 150 words.

item.title: Support for all-ages performances among changes proposed for NSW's live music scene
item.description: The state government introduces what it describes as a "world first" bill to support the live music scene.

item.title: US man linked to Wieambilla shooting sentenced to three years' prison
item.description: A US-based conspiracy theorist with links to the Wieambilla shooters is handed a three-year sentence for firearms offences.

item.title: Out of 38,000 people fined for non-voting in NT local government elections just 3 per cent have paid
item.description: Just 3 per cent of voters fined for not voting in last year’s Northern Territory local government elections have paid the penalty. Debate is growing over whether the system is working — or unfair to voters in remote areas.

item.title: Tim Picton's accused killer Brodie Dewar says Labor identity made unwanted advances on cousin
item.description: A man who allegedly killed Tim Picton in a one-punch attack outside a Perth nightclub claims the Labor identity had repeatedly approached his female cousin before being escorted out of the venue because he was intoxicated, a Perth court hears.

item.title: Cigarette lighter prompts gun scare near Hyde Park girls' school
item.description: A man spotted with what was initially believed to be a gun near a shopping centre in Adelaide's inner south will face court charged with the assault of an emergency worker, police say.

item.title: Sydney children's author Oliver Phommavanh jailed for sending sexually explicit messages to minors
item.description: Oliver Phommavanh is sentenced to six-and-a-half years in prison with a non-parole period of four years.

item.title: Woman dead, son in coma as detectives probe alleged Albany homicide
item.description: Detectives say the son of a 69-year-old woman found dead in Albany is being treated as a suspect in her alleged homicide.

item.title: Friday Finance with David Chau
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: Coroner finds police tactic not the cause of Toowoomba Indigenous man's death in custody
item.description: A Queensland coroner finds the cause of Indigenous man Steven Nixon-McKellar's death during an arrest was "multi-factorial".

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026: Josie Baff claims Australia's second gold with stunning snowboard cross triumph
item.description: Josie Baff has become Australia's second gold medallist at the Milano Cortina Winter Olympics, claiming victory in the women's snowboard cross.

item.title: Ley didn't define herself by her gender but women might relate to her workplace woes
item.description: The issue for the Liberal Party is not simply the toppling of a female leader. It's also about what happened to that leader while she was in the job.

item.title: From Japan to Israel, elections are reshaping global politics
item.description: At a time when so much of the global conversation is about the rapid decline of democracy, it is striking what a huge impact elections are having on world events just now.

item.title: Josie Baff wins 2026 Winter Olympic gold, a testament to the power of self-belief
item.description: Self-belief is the most powerful tool at an athlete's disposal, and Josie Baff utilised it to its fullest extent with a magical run to gold in the 2026 Winter Olympics snowboard cross.

item.title: Here's what we know about Angus Taylor's policies
item.description: The new Liberal leader has signalled he will pursue a stricter immigration policy and a return to "Australian values" in his first pitch to win back voters.

item.title: Today in history, February 14: Torvill and Dean perform 'perfect' Bolero to win gold at Winter Olympics
item.description: Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean were already hot favourites for a gold medal. But on the ice in Sarajevo, the British ice dancers provided a performance of perfect artistry that made Olympic history.

item.title: Michael Mohammed Ahmad confronts traumatic childhood abuse in his new novel, Bugger
item.description: Michael Mohammed Ahmad, author of The Lebs, marks turning 40 with the publication of his most confronting novel yet.

item.title: The very unusual factor in the Nancy Guthrie missing person case
item.description: What initially seemed like a high-profile kidnapping that might be resolved with a multi-million-dollar bank transfer has now morphed into something else.

item.title: Japanese lagers thrive as Kirin and Asahi loom over Australia's beer market
item.description: As record numbers of Australians continue to visit Japan, Japanese brewers have come to dominate our domestic beer market.

item.title: Courtney's doctor operated seven times to treat severe endometriosis experts say she didn't have
item.description: Pathology from Courtney's seven surgeries with Dr Simon Gordon repeatedly showed no signs of endometriosis. The surgeries left her medically infertile.

item.title: Residents in conservative Farrer eye future without Sussan Ley
item.description: Just minutes after deposed Liberal leader Sussan Ley announced her resignation, constituents in her electorate of Farrer began murmuring about change.

item.title: The Allan government is under fire over corruption, but the premier is sticking to her guns
item.description: Pressure is mounting on Premier Jacinta Allan, as she challenges claims that billions in taxpayer dollars were funnelled to criminals via the CFMEU under her watch.

item.title: Scotty James wins silver medal in snowboard halfpipe at 2026 Milano Cortina Winter Olympic Games
item.description: Scotty James has fallen short of an elusive Olympic gold, instead claiming a second silver medal in the snowboard halfpipe.

item.title: DNA genealogy is changing the way NSW Police investigate cold cases
item.description: Australians looking to learn more about their heritage through commercial ancestry websites could be helping police solve cold cases.

item.title: Melbourne Storm accused by Parramatta Eels of asking NRL to intervene in Zac Lomax contract saga
item.description: Melbourne has been accused of asking NRL chief executive Andrew Abdo to "apply a blowtorch" to Parramatta as part of a desperate bid to sign Zac Lomax to the Storm.

item.title: NSW Waratahs defeat Queensland Reds 36-12 in opening round of Super Rugby Pacific
item.description: The NSW Waratahs are in celebration mode after breaking the shackles to open the Super Rugby Pacific season with a rousing 36-12 derby win over the Queensland Reds in Sydney.

item.title: Community, experts reflect on lessons from Black Saturday fires 17 years on
item.description: Seventeen years after Black Saturday, experts reflect on what was learnt from the disaster and how it informs Victoria's current bushfire response.

item.title: Israeli President Isaac Herzog's visit draws criticism and praise from Jewish and Muslim groups
item.description: Two months after the deadly Bondi Beach terrorist attack, Israeli President Isaac Herzog's visit was meant to comfort a grieving community. Instead, it ignited protests and deepened divisions.

item.title: Musical Matches: Harpist Emily Granger and composer Tristan Coelho
item.description: For Valentine's Day, this Australian composer wrote his wife a harp concerto. She's about to premiere it with the Queensland Symphony Orchestra.

item.title: Sturla Holm Lægreid's well-intentioned display left a prince looking froggy
item.description: It was a new high, or low, in performative relationship management for a generation who believe a flipped screen and a full-face confession of "accountability" can solve any problem.

item.title: GPS collars, camera traps to see if foxes are swimming into Booderee National Park
item.description: Camera traps, GPS collars and DNA testing are being used on foxes at Booderee National Park as efforts to control the pests intensify.

item.description: While growing up, people didn't make much sense to Summer, but chickens always did. Now, Summer is using what they learnt to help other children with autism understand human interactions.

item.title: Man, 18, in custody over alleged carjacking attempt in Hobart CBD
item.description: An 18-year-old man who allegedly used a screwdriver in an attempt to carjack a car with a woman and her two children inside in the middle of Hobart was overpowered by onlookers, Tasmania Police say.

item.description: Marriage is still a life goal in Indonesia, but the number of marriages has plummeted over the past decade.

item.title: Remember Dollar Bill? It's been 60 years since Australia made the big change to decimal currency
item.description: Six decades ago, Australia swapped its old currency for dollars and cents. A catchy jingle sung by a cartoon character named Dollar Bill helped the country adapt.

item.title: Parents fail to return consent forms as Far North Queensland HPV vaccination rate drops
item.description: Cairns Public Health Unit says students are increasingly missing their school HPV vaccinations because they do not have parental consent.

item.description: Want a prepped breakfast with plenty of protein? These omelette sandwiches keep for three days in the fridge, ready to pop in a sandwich press in the morning.

item.description: Phillip Ellis Wells was solo diving roughly 7 kilometres off the east coast of Tasmania when he noticed a shadow pass overhead.

item.title: Innovative cattle loading ramp puts animal welfare at centre of design
item.description: A retired truck driver has developed a wide, steel, cattle-loading ramp that allows animals to walk side by side, mimicking natural herd behaviour and reducing noise, agitation and the risk of injury during transport.

item.title: Scotty James left numb by the tragedy of 'almost' at 2026 Milano Cortina Winter Olympic Games

item.title: Jane Hume was punished for her election slips. Now she's been crowned deputy Liberal leader
item.description: The Victorian senator was unceremoniously turfed from Sussan Ley's ministry after being tarred personally with much of what went wrong in the Coalition's cataclysmic loss. On Friday, she ascended to the Liberal's second-in-command.

item.description: An ancient burial mask, cat figurine and jewellery are among the "priceless" Egyptian artefacts stolen from the Abbey Museum of Art and Archaeology yesterday.

item.description: South Molle Island's former resort has been abandoned since it was damaged by a cyclone in 2017. Now, public access to the island is restricted after Cyclone Koji wreaked havoc on its jetty.

item.description: The rural-based social program in the shadow of Mt Tamborine has had remarkable success in rebuilding the lives of youth who have fallen through the cracks.

item.description: After years of delays, the Pilbara's largest carbon emitters are testing greener ways to haul iron ore, and Andrew Forrest has now joined their ranks.

item.description: Winning Victoria coach Chris Scott and his Western Australia counterpart Dean Cox call for State of Origin to be played every year after the concept's stunning return in Perth.

item.description: The South Australian and federal government release plans for the shipyard in Adelaide that will build at least eight nuclear-powered submarines under the AUKUS pact with the US and the UK.

item.description: Four boats are destroyed in a fire at Hillarys Boat Harbour, the second time a blaze has struck the marina in just over four months.

item.description: The Indigenous team overturns a 14-0 deficit to score a rousing comeback win over the Maori in the Women's All Stars clash.

item.description: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned by the Kremlin with a rare and lethal toxin found in the skin of poison dart frogs, five European countries have said. It's not the first time the country has been accused of poisoning its enemies.

item.title: Matt Graham wins dual moguls bronze at the 2026 Winter Olympics
item.description: Matt Graham's medal is the third Australia’s moguls squad has delivered at the Milano Cortina Winter Olympics.

item.title: Ukrainian drone strike sparks fires at Russian Black Sea port ahead of peace talks
item.description: Two people are wounded in an attack on the port of Taman in the Krasnodar region, ahead of US-brokered peace talks between Ukraine and Russia.

item.title: City of Melbourne quiet on plan for Southbank's 'ugly' red stairs, long after design competition announced
item.description: A Melbourne council unveiled a lucrative competition to replace Southbank's much-derided red stairs. But a year after it was due to start, the plan appears to have gone nowhere.

item.title: Today in History, February 16: Steven Bradbury's Winter Olympic Games golden miracle at Salt Lake City in 2002
item.description: In 2002, Australia broke its Winter Olympics gold medal duck in the most extraordinary of ways, as Steven Bradbury put a decade of injury and bad luck behind him to claim the most thrilling of gold medals.

item.title: This week in history quiz, February 16: Can you pass the test?
item.description: Abraham Lincoln's career advice, Karl Marx's co-author and a Hollywood star's surgery: How well do you know history?

item.title: What is FAFO parenting and is it good for kids?
item.description: Is FAFO the 1980s parenting style today's generation of kids need, rebellion against gentle child-rearing, or exhausted parents just throwing their hands in the air?

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026: The anxiety and joy of dual moguls bronze for Matt Graham, leader and captain of the Australian team
item.description: Matt Graham's brilliant bronze in the dual moguls, and the incredible response from his teammates, proved to everyone that he is the true leader of this Winter Olympic squad.

item.title: Liberal Party divided over policy direction as Angus Taylor plots right-wing political shift
item.description: Angus Taylor says he will unite the Liberal Party, but a deeper rift is forming between those who want to overhaul the party's direction and those who believe doing so would mean political death.

item.title: ACCC takes Coles to court over 'illusory' discounts in 'case of the century'
item.description: The "case of the century" is set to play out in the federal court this month, with the ACCC taking on supermarket giant Coles for what it claims are "illusory" discounts.

item.title: AI is evolving fast and may bring the fourth industrial revolution with it
item.description: A fake news story about me, a series of AI breakthroughs and a resignation in the tech world show that 2026 could be pivotal for AI.

item.title: Alex de Minaur claims Rotterdam Open with impressive victory over Felix Auger-Aliassime
item.description: An inspired Alex de Minaur produces one of the biggest wins of his career, lifting the Rotterdam Open title by beating red-hot Felix Auger-Aliassime.

item.title: Whooping cough cases hit record high after 'potentially catastrophic' vaccine rate drop
item.description: A "potentially catastrophic" decline in Australia's childhood vaccination rates has contributed to the sharpest increase in cases of whooping cough in 35 years, infectious diseases experts say.

item.title: As high-speed rail plans gather pace, Britain's HS2 offers hard lessons
item.description: While the federal government considers an ambitious plan, a similar project in the UK has seen its fair share of controversies.

item.title: Australia defeated by India in opening T20 as Sophie Molineux era gets off to wobbly start
item.description: Australia slumps to a rain-affected 21-run loss to India in their opening T20 at the SCG, after selectors opted to drop vice-captain Tahlia McGrath.

item.title: From wheels to waves in Australia's queer spaces
item.description: In places marked by historic violence and exclusion, queer communities are still showing up.

item.title: Box Hill North players' sanctions over inappropriate photos criticised as 'extremely lenient'
item.description: The Box Hill North Football Club players involved in inappropriate photos posted online after their "Silly Saturday" post-season celebrations have been sanctioned by the league's governing body.

item.title: Cousin of Westfield Bondi Junction attack victim feels many questions were left unanswered at inquest
item.description: A bereaved family member of victim Jade Young feels many of his questions surrounding the deadly attack and its aftermath have been left unanswered from the inquest.

item.title: Anthony Kim's LIV Adelaide victory an inspiring chapter in one of golf's most harrowing stories
item.description: American Anthony Kim, who has overcome alcohol and drug addiction, hopes his emotional win at LIV Golf's Adelaide tournament will inspire others.

item.title: Shark population may have fallen prey to algal bloom, SA ecologists fear
item.description: South Australia's algal bloom could be responsible for pushing a local population of sharks to the brink of collapse, some researchers say.

item.title: India and Pakistan refuse handshakes before and after contentious T20 World Cup clash
item.description: India and Pakistan decline to shake hands before and after the most-anticipated game of the T20 World Cup, with India easily winning by 61 runs to secure its Super 8 spot.

item.title: Cape Barren Island uses greenhouse and traditional foods to keep fridges full
item.description: A tiny island off the coast of Tasmania is embracing old and new techniques to keep food on the table.

item.title: Live: 'Utterly misleading': ACCC argues case against Coles' 'discounts'
item.description: Supermarket giant Coles and the consumer watchdog are in the Federal Court. The ASX rises as reporting season continues in earnest. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

item.title: Live: Taylor expected to reward allies with shadow cabinet positions within days
item.description: Speculation is mounting over who will be promoted to the shadow cabinet after Angus Taylor's elevation to the leadership. Follow live.

item.title: Dams and rivers run dry, forcing Victorian farmers to make tough decisions about their livestock
item.description: Victorian farmers are forced to cart water or destock as dams and rivers run dry.

item.title: Flood warnings across Qld as the state's north braces for heavy falls
item.description: All eyes are on already-swollen waterways across Queensland as the state's north braces for another drenching this week.

item.title: Rescuers race to find entangled whale last seen near Wilsons Promontory
item.description: Authorities are looking for a juvenile humpback whale last seen entangled in rope off the coast near Wilsons Promontory.

item.title: DNA recovered from glove found near Guthrie home that appears to match suspect's glove, FBI says
item.description: The FBI says a glove containing DNA was found near the home of US TV show host Savannah Guthrie's mother and appears to match those worn by a masked person outside her front door the night she vanished.

item.title: How the ABC Young Performers Awards helped launch the careers of these Australian musicians
item.description: The ABC Young Performers Awards have launched the careers of some of Australia's most successful musicians. Here are some of their stories.

item.title: Fisheries compliance officers inspection November 2023
item.description: Follow the latest headlines from ABC News, Australia's most trusted media source, with live events, audio and on-demand video from the national broadcaster.

item.title: Future of fishing prosecutions unclear after multi-million-dollar abalone trafficking case collapses
item.description: Subpoenaed documents obtained by the ABC reveal NSW Police continued prosecuting seven men for illegally trafficking abalone despite advice that their case was likely to fail.

item.title: Why Australian Adam Lambert's medal-losing crash in the final made him feel better about his Winter Olympics
item.description: Adam Lambert's crash in the mixed snowboard cross cost Australia a chance at a medal at the 2026 Winter Olympic Games, but it still makes him feel better about his campaign.

item.title: Queensland school teacher calls for endometriosis support after fundraising for surgery
item.description: After years of unsuccessful endometriosis treatments, Inez Goves underwent a hysterectomy thanks to an online fundraiser. But her symptoms returned, prompting more surgery and calls for greater support for the illness.

item.title: Sydney scientist collects wild roadside apples to produce cider
item.description: Lucien Alperstein has spent the past decade picking feral apples from trees along country back roads and making cider. They say their guerilla activity inspired their curiosity about the science of genetics and fermentation.

item.title: Chalmers mocks Taylor's proposal for bipartisan budget savings taskforce
item.description: Angus Taylor wrote to the prime minister pitching the plan just days after being elected leader of the Liberal Party.

item.title: Halls Gap businesses reinventing themselves after bushfires wiped out trade
item.description: After two consecutive summers devastated by bushfires, businesses in the region are reinventing themselves to stay afloat.

item.title: SA Police return to Oak Park Station in Gus Lamont missing person investigation
item.description: Officers are at Oak Park Station in South Australia's north-east, where a four-year-old boy went missing almost five months ago.

item.title: Meet GayC/DC, the world's only all-gay AC/DC tribute band
item.description: They worship the riffs, rewrite the lyrics and win over the toughest crowds. GayC/DC is a tribute band like no other.

item.title: Israeli air strikes target Gaza Palestinians just days before Board of Peace meeting
item.description: US President Donald Trump says the first meeting of his newly created Board of Peace will take place on Thursday, with over $7 billion to be pledged for reconstruction and humanitarian efforts in Gaza.

item.title: Traditional owners 'won't accept' handback of rehabilitated Argyle diamond mine site
item.description: East Kimberley traditional owners are concerned Rio Tinto's closure plan will leave them with "a giant hole in the ground forever".

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026: Matt Graham on dual moguls 'dad podium' as weather forces reschedule — quick hits from day nine
item.description: A trio of dads fill the dual moguls podium as an "unfavourable" forecast leaves things up in the air. Here are the quick hits from day nine of the Milano Cortina Games.

item.title: Vermilion's Wandoo gas exports halted after December oil spill
item.description: Exports from an oil field off WA's Pilbara are at a standstill after an oil spill in December. The regulator says it has identified "systemic failures" at the Canadian-owned Wandoo facility.

item.title: Bondi Beach terror attack gunman Naveed Akram appears in court for the first time
item.description: Bondi Beach gunman Naveed Akram, who is charged with 15 counts of murder, has appeared via video link for the first time in a Sydney court as a senior magistrate extended existing suppression orders in the case.

item.title: Police make 'very strange' appeal for return of kidnapped 85yo Sydney man
item.description: Detectives believe Chris Baghsarian was mistakenly snatched from his bedroom just after 5am on Friday by intruders who forced their way into his North Ryde property.

item.title: Antarctic type B killer whales seen for first time near WA's Bremer Bay
item.description: Sightings of Antarctic orcas in Australian waters are very rare. A tour group in WA saw what appeared to be a pod of Antarctic type B killer whales muscle in and steal the meal of a local group of orcas.

item.title: Brett Pointing to replace Steve Gollschewski as Queensland police commissioner on 12-month interim basis
item.description: Brett Pointing has been named as the interim Queensland police commissioner after Steve Gollschewski announced his retirement.

item.title: New tobacco laws proposed by WA government to target stores selling illegal cigarettes, vapes
item.description: Western Australia could soon have some of the nation's toughest tobacco laws, after months of pressure to overhaul the state's aging legislation.

item.title: Migrants who breach Australian values would be kicked out under Ley-era policy draft
item.description: A leaked copy of the Liberal Party's migration policy prepared before Sussan Ley was ousted included plans to "elevate" the current non-binding Australian values statement.

item.title: NRL opens door for New Zealand and England internationals to play State of Origin
item.description: New South Wales and Queensland can now select players who are New Zealand and England internationals after the NRL confirmed a major change to the State of Origin eligibility rules.

item.title: Increased use of pepper spray, police weapons at protests alarm rights groups
item.description: Alarmed by a spike in pepper spray use and threats of sound cannons at protests, human rights groups want a review of "less lethal" weapons for crowd control.

item.title: ACCC accuses Coles of 'planned' campaign to mislead customers
item.description: Supermarket giant Coles is accused of a "planned" campaign to mislead customers over discounts on the first day of a bombshell Federal Court case.

item.title: Canberra man accused of stalking couple and leaving them notes denied bail in ACT Magistrates Court
item.description: The man allegedly went to the married couple's home four times in two months, seeking access while claiming to be an arborist on one occasion, and attempting to remove the home's doorbell camera on another.

item.title: From the weird to the wonderful, here are nine times politicians have become a meme
item.description: From the downright weird to the speech that soared, Australia's politicians are under constant scrutiny. Here are some startling moments when the politician became the meme.

item.title: Man accused of Caboolture museum heist allegedly believed it was his 'duty' to return artefacts to 'rightful place', court told
item.description: Miguel Simon Mungarrieta Monsalve has been charged with a range of offences after he allegedly broke into a Caboolture museum on Friday morning.

item.title: Maugean skate still faces 'catastrophic' risk from salmon farming, Commonwealth advice says
item.description: Official advice is unequivocal that salmon farming remains the main threat to the endangered Maugean skate. It remains to be seen if the federal environment minister will ask Tasmanian salmon farms to scale back their operations.

item.title: 'Signal sniffers' used in search for missing person Nancy Guthrie's pacemaker
item.description: The FBI is using "sophisticated" technology to try to locate Nancy Guthrie's pacemaker, as the search for the mother of US TV host Savannah Guthrie enters its third week.

item.title: Hospital boss says changes already made at child gender service criticised in review
item.description: Advocates have called for for better regional services after a Cairns children gender clinic was restricted following a scathing report.

item.title: Perth Diving Academy Hillarys fined almost $20,000 after leaving two divers in ocean
item.description: Perth Diving Academy Hillarys is fined almost $20,000 after an Australian Maritime Safety Authority probe found it had

item.title: Firearms charges laid amid search for Gus Lamont, SA Police say unrelated to disappearance
item.description: Detectives investigating the case of missing boy Gus Lamont have made an arrest during their renewed search for evidence – but say it does not relate to his disappearance.

item.title: Heat, storms lead to extreme fire forecast across dry Victoria tomorrow
item.description: Almost half the state is expected to face extreme fire conditions tomorrow due to a mix of heat, dry fuels and gusty afternoon storms.

item.title: Protester takes to roof of Geraldton fisheries building over WA government's demersal fishing ban
item.description: Fisherman John Higham has taken to the roof of the Deparment of Industries and Regional Development building in Geraldton to protest the Cook government's restrictions.

item.title: How cheating allegations have rocked the curling teams at the Olympics
item.description: Controversy is swirling in curling at the Winter Olympics after the Canadian team was accused of cheating. Here's a look at the whole controversy and why it matters.

item.title: Wotjobaluk Nations and Tati Tati formally enter Victorian Treaty negotiations register
item.description: Wotjobaluk Nations and Tati Tati traditional owners have joined Victoria's formal Treaty negotiations register, building on decades of work towards recognition and self-determination.

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026 quick guide: What to watch on Day 10
item.description: Find out what is on during Day 10 at the Winter Olympics in Milan.
